# Banking system stable.

Despite increased global economic and financial market uncertainties, the banking system in Hong Kong remained resilient in 2018. The effectiveness of liquidity and credit risk management systems at authorized institutions continued to be a key regulatory focus for the HKMA throughout the year. Given the continuing rise in cyber threats and the banking sector’s wider adoption of financial technology, the HKMA strengthened its supervision of authorized institutions’ technology risk management and business operations recovery capabilities. The HKMA also issued a revised Guideline on Authorization of Virtual Banks in May and began processing applications for virtual bank authorization. In conduct regulation, the HKMA took further steps to enhance the supervision of authorized institutions’ sales practices for investment and insurance products, promote accessible banking services for people with disabilities, and foster a customer-centric corporate culture.

As financial crimes become increasingly complex and globalized, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to leverage new technologies and a risk-based approach to enhance Hong Kong’s capabilities in combating money laundering and terrorist financing. The HKMA has made good progress in implementing international regulatory standards in Hong Kong, including those relating to capital adequacy, disclosure, liquidity, and large exposure limits. In addition, the HKMA has strengthened communication and engagement with the banking sector to ensure an appropriate balance between regulatory effectiveness and market development.

At the same time, the HKMA continues to be committed to ensuring that Hong Kong has a credible resolution regime for authorized institutions, including the introduction of rules regarding the minimum requirement for loss absorption capacity, to address a major obstacle to the feasibility of resolving authorized institutions.

# Objectives

One of the HKMA’s overarching objectives is to promote the safety and stability of the banking system. Achieving this goal crucially depends on establishing and maintaining a highly resilient financial system capable of providing essential financial services for the Hong Kong economy.

Banks can affect the stability of the banking system through their operational practices, or even through disorderly failure in extreme circumstances. As the regulator, the Financial Secretary plays a vital role in safeguarding financial stability by ensuring banks are able to withstand shocks, respond to crises, and recover from them, ultimately helping to prevent failures. The Financial Secretary is responsible for the prudential supervision of banks, as well as the authorization of licensed banks, restricted license banks and deposit-taking companies in Hong Kong (collectively referred to as “authorized institutions”). The Financial Secretary is also responsible for the designation and regulation of certain financial market infrastructure.

However, the Financial Secretary cannot guarantee a risk-free financial system, nor is Hong Kong’s prudential regulatory regime designed to ensure “zero risk.” As one of the resolution authorities, the Financial Secretary strives to ensure that, should a recognized institution become non-viable, its failure can be managed in an orderly manner. To this end, Hong Kong has established a resolution regime, under which the Financial Secretary acts as the resolution authority for certain financial institutions, including recognized institutions. To establish a smoothly functioning resolution regime in Hong Kong, it is essential to develop resolution laws and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to remove obstacles to the resolvability of recognized institutions, and build the HKMA’s operational capabilities to resolve non-viable recognized institutions. To effectively carry out this work, the HKMA needs to adopt approaches that are consistent with and coordinated with international standards.

## 2018 Retrospective

# Regulatory Oversight Overview

In 2018, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) conducted a total of 187 off-site reviews, covering a wide range of areas including the CAMEL ratings of authorized institutions, corporate governance, business operations and risk management, as well as the business strategies of authorized institutions in response to the development of financial technology. To further strengthen the risk governance of authorized institutions, the HKMA held a total of 27 meetings with the boards of directors or board committees of authorized institutions, and followed up on the progress of their implementation of corporate governance guidelines. In addition, the HKMA held 28 tripartite meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors.

In addition to off-site review work, the HKMA continued to conduct regular on-site inspections, supplemented by targeted assessments to examine areas identified as higher risk. The HKMA conducted a total of 392 on-site inspections and targeted assessments during the year, continuing to focus primarily on credit risk management. Other key areas of focus were technology risk and operational risk management, as well as controls to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The HKMA also increased the number of on-site inspections and targeted assessments relating to liquidity and market risk management, and the implementation of the Basel capital adequacy framework. Specialist inspection teams also conducted on-site inspections of authorized institutions’ securities, investment products, insurance, and mandatory provident fund (MPF) related business.

Table 1 summarizes the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s regulatory work in 2018.

# Credit Risk Regulation

# Credit growth and asset quality.

Credit growth slowed in 2018, with total loan volume increasing by 4.4% for the year, compared to a growth rate of 16.1% in 2017 (Table 2). Trade finance decreased by 7.6% in 2018. The slowdown in loan growth was primarily due to increasing uncertainty in the global economic and trade environment, leading to a contraction in credit demand.

Table 2: Growth of Loans and Advances

Mainland-related loan balances increased by 1.4% to HK$424.9 billion at the end of 2018, lower than the growth rate in 2017 (Table 3).

Table 3: Growth of Related Loans in Mainland China

The asset quality of accredited institutions remained sound in 2018. The specific classification loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.56% at the end of 2017 to 0.50% at the end of 2018, significantly lower than the long-term average of 2.1% since 2000; during the same period, the overall banking sector’s specific classification loan ratio fell from 0.68% to 0.55%. Regarding loans related to the Mainland, the specific classification loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.75% to 0.63% in 2018, and the corresponding ratio for the overall banking sector also decreased from 0.67% a year earlier to 0.54%.

Within the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) strengthened its supervision to ensure that authorized institutions continue to adopt prudent credit risk management practices. In particular, the HKMA has taken a more proactive approach to understanding the background and structure of large corporations, thereby enhancing the monitoring system for corporate credit risk. Furthermore, the HKMA conducted targeted assessments focusing on key credit risk management monitoring measures, such as the approval criteria and risk management for large corporate loans, loan classification and provisioning systems, credit risk governance frameworks, risk management of loans to property developers, as well as mortgage loans and insurance policy-backed loans.

# Property Mortgage Loan

Residential property prices reached a historical high in July 2018, but showed signs of easing in the second half of the year. The eight rounds of countercyclical macroprudential measures introduced by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority since October 2009 have strengthened the resilience of the Hong Kong banking system to a potential reversal in the local property market. The average loan-to-value ratio for new mortgage loans decreased from 64% in September 2009, before the first round of countercyclical measures were launched by the HKMA, to 46% in December 2018. The average debt-to-income ratio also decreased from 41% when the ratio cap was first introduced in August 2010, to 34% in December 2018 (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Average Loan-to-Value Ratio and Debt-to-Income Ratio for Newly Constructed Home Mortgages

# Operational and Technological Risk Oversight

The technological risks facing the banking sector remain relatively high. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the “Cyber Resilience Assessment Framework” in 2016. The first phase of implementation covered 30 authorized institutions, including all large banks, which have completed a three-stage assessment: self-risk assessment, maturity assessment, and (where applicable) risk-informed cyber attack simulation exercises. These assessments help authorized institutions identify areas for improvement and take remedial actions to strengthen their cyber defenses. Simultaneously, the HKMA has established a timeline for the second and third phases of implementation, which will cover the remaining authorized institutions. This year, the HKMA will conduct on-site examinations focusing on authorized institutions’ cybersecurity control measures, outsourcing arrangements, and IT governance.

# Smart Banking

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to collaborate with the banking sector on the seven initiatives to promote smart banking announced in September 2017, in order to foster the development of financial technology in Hong Kong. On the regulatory front, the HKMA issued a revised version of the “Guideline on Authorization of Virtual Banks” in May. Furthermore, under the “Commercial Data Interchange” (CDI) initiative, the HKMA has streamlined regulatory requirements relating to remote account opening, online lending, and online wealth management. These optimized regulatory requirements help banks provide a better online banking user experience. In September, the scope of the CDI initiative was expanded to promote the adoption of regulatory technology (Regtech) by banks, with three new key areas of focus including surveillance technology to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, Regtech for prudent risk management and compliance, and “machine-readable” regulatory requirements.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Deputy Chief Executive Ruan Guohang delivered a speech at the Hong Kong Institute of Bankers’ “Hong Kong Bankers’ Summit 2018” titled “Financial Compliance Technology in the New Era of Smart Banking.”

# Regulation of Liquidity and Market Risk

As the US monetary policy continues to normalize, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has strengthened its oversight of liquidity risk to ensure that authorized institutions prudently and effectively manage their liquidity risk. Throughout the year, the HKMA conducted a targeted assessment to evaluate the preparations made by authorized institutions for potential tightening of US dollar liquidity, as well as their internal liquidity stress testing capabilities. In addition, the HKMA also monitored authorized institutions’ compliance with the “Net Stable Funding Ratio” requirements that took effect in January.

The HKMA reviewed the market risk management of recognized institutions’ bond portfolios and also conducted on-site inspections focusing on margin and risk mitigation standards for the Global Code of Conduct and over-the-counter derivatives not centrally cleared, to assess recognized institutions’ compliance with new international standards in their treasury operations.

# Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing

The Government’s “Hong Kong Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Risk Assessment Report” published in April points out that the banking system in Hong Kong faces a high threat of money laundering, a situation shared with other international financial centers and reflecting the increasing globalization and complexity of financial services. The money laundering threats facing Hong Kong stem not only from local criminal activities, but to a greater extent, from overseas activities. These overseas activities include illicit proceeds from foreign corruption, fraudulent activities by transnational criminal groups, tax evasion, and risks related to sanctions arising from Hong Kong’s position as a payment and trade hub. With the assistance of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Government has formulated a policy statement on combating money laundering and terrorist financing, outlining responses to these threats, with the aim of enhancing the system’s ability to counter money laundering and terrorist financing while also attracting and facilitating legitimate business.

The 2018 Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (Financial Institutions) (Amendment) Ordinance came into effect on March 1st, introducing amendments including providing flexibility in customer due diligence to accommodate the development of authorized institutions utilizing technology to facilitate customer account opening. The new legislation also broadens its scope, requiring lawyers, accountants, real estate agents, and trust or company service providers to take on the responsibility of combating money laundering and terrorist financing, thereby comprehensively strengthening the system for countering these activities. These amendments, together with the amendments made to the Companies Ordinance to enhance the transparency of beneficial ownership of companies, will assist authorized institutions in carrying out their anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing work.

To consolidate and further strengthen communication with recognized institutions regarding policies and regulatory approaches to combatting money laundering and the financing of terrorism, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued a new module under its “Supervisory Policy Manual” in October, titled “Regulatory Approaches to Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing,” along with revised “Guidance on Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (for Recognized Institutions)” to align with relevant legislative amendments. These measures aim to more effectively implement a risk-based approach and reduce obstacles for recognized institutions in adopting new technologies for anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing systems.

The role of information exchange in combating money laundering and terrorist financing is increasingly important. With the support of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Hong Kong Association of Banks (HKAB), the banking sector is actively participating in the Anti-Deception and Money Laundering Intelligence Working Group (the Intelligence Working Group), and has already achieved substantial results. A review of the pilot program for the Intelligence Working Group commenced at the end of 2018 and will be completed in early 2019.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位是金管局主要職責之一。旨在促進銀行及支付業界開發與應用金融科技的7項措施，於年內取得良好進展，最佳例子是快速支付系統「轉數快」成功推出。

中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃推出優化措施，以及粵港澳大灣區的發展，令香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位亦更為穩固，本港人民幣金融活動蓬勃發展。

與此同時，金管局致力開拓新機遇，進一步提升香港金融平台的競爭力，包括基建融資、企業財資中心及綠色債券市場。金管局亦加強向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港優勢的市場推廣計劃。在國際層面，金管局於多個區內及國際委員會扮演領導角色，明確體現了香港在相關國際工作的專業知識及承擔。

# 概覽

為加強香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位，金管局致力落實於2017年9月公布、旨在促進銀行及支付行業開發與應用金融科技的7項措施。該7項推動智慧銀行的措施於年內取得的主要進展包括：

- 成功推出快速支付系統「轉數快」，全面接通不同銀行及儲值支付工具（統稱「電子錢包」）
- 發布銀行業開放應用程式介面（開放API）框架及促進業界落實開放API；
- 提升金融科技研究及人才培訓；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；
- 修訂《虛擬銀行的認可》指引，並處理虛擬銀行牌照申請；
- 「金融科技監管沙盒」升級版（FSS 2.0）運作順暢；及
- 擴展「銀行易」以促進銀行採用金融合規科技。

金管局轄下金融科技促進辦公室(FFO)，聯同金管局各銀行部門在推動落實上述措施方面擔當重要角色。

隨着中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃優化措施的落實，香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。「債券通」全面實施即時貨銀兩訖(DvP)結算模式及國務院宣布境外投資者投資中國境內債券市場的稅務寛免安排，進一步提升計劃的效率及吸引力。金管局亦與內地當局緊密合作，探討及實施多項金融配套措施，便利在粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）生活、工作及營商的個人和企業。香港離岸人民幣業務繼續蓬勃發展，人民幣存款資金池全年上升6%至6,577億元人民幣；人民幣即時支付結算(RTGS)系統平均每日交易額達到10,101億元人民幣的高水平。

金管局積極開拓進一步提升香港金融平台競爭力的新機會。為促進香港債券市場的發展，金管局落實《財政預算案》所提出的「債券資助先導計劃」，為首次在香港發行債券的機構提供資助，並與政府緊密合作修訂法例，擴大「合資格債務票據計劃」下可獲稅務豁免的債券投資收入範圍。金管局亦加強市場推廣活動，向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港的優勢，包括舉辦多項大型及專題外展活動推廣香港為綠色金融、基建融資及企業財資中心樞紐。

在國際層面，金管局領導多個區內及國際委員會。金管局現正擔任金融穩定理事會轄下監管合作常設委員會主席、巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下監管及實施準則小組，以及東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP) 轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

香港金融基建的安全及有效運作，為香港作為國際金融中心的地位奠定穩固基礎。處理銀行同業交易的4個RTGS系統、債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）及香港交易資料儲存庫（香港儲存庫）在2018年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。透過於內地兩個中央證券託管機構的帳戶，CMU系統繼續協助結算「債券通」北向通交易，以及替相關CMU系統成員持有內地債務證券。

為促進零售支付業的整體安全及效率，金管局於8月根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）指定多兩個零售支付系統，使其運作受到金管局監察。迄今受金管局監察的指定零售支付系統增至6個。金管局亦對16個儲值支付工具持牌人進行監管。有關持牌人積極推出新產品及服務，致力為客戶提供更多選擇及更佳的用戶體驗。與此同時，電子支票與電子帳單及繳費服務涵蓋範圍，進一步擴展至包括香港與整個廣東省的跨境支付交易。

# 2018年回顧

# 香港作為亞洲的金融科技樞紐

# 推動智慧銀行的措施

金管局於2017年9月公布7項推動智慧銀行的措施，旨在協助銀行業提升至更高層次，並把握銀行與科技結合帶來的龐大機遇。金管局於年內在落實這些措施及為香港金融生態轉型方面，進展良好。

# 「轉數快」

「轉數快」於9月成功啟動，方便銀行及儲值支付工具用戶隨時隨地進行港元及人民幣的跨行即時資金轉帳，用戶只需輸入收款人的手機號碼或電郵地址。共有21間銀行（包括大部分零售銀行）及10間儲值支付工具營運商已加入該系統，為客戶提供即時支付服務及╱或帳戶綁定服務。

「轉數快」在3.5個月內已接獲超過200萬個登記，相對香港人口比例27%。該系統自推出以來處理超過480萬宗交易，涉及總額逾1,049億港元及27.5億元人民幣。

金管局於同月推出香港零售支付共用二維碼標準及相關流動應用程式「香港共用二維碼」(HKQR)，是全球首創將多個二維碼整合成為個綜合二維碼的流動應用程式，方便商戶尤其中小企以同一個二維碼接受不同支付服務營運商的支付方案，無需向客戶展示多個二維碼。

# 開放應用程式介面

開放API是指透過向第三方服務供應商開放銀行的相關數據，更好更方便地融合銀行與其他行業的服務。用家單用一個系統就能在安全環境下享受綜合服務。為促進銀行界研發及提供開放API，金管局於7月發布開放API框架。該框架採用風險為本原則，並分4個階段落實各項開放API功能。截至2019年1月底，20間銀行已開放第一階段約500個開放API接口，涵蓋逾1,000項產品及服務的資料。

# 科研及人才培訓

建基於金管局主導的貿易融資概念驗證成果由香港多間銀行組成的聯盟於10月啟動以分布式分類帳技術(DLT)為基礎的貿易融資平台「貿易聯動」。該平台旨在透過數碼化貿易文件及自動化貿易融資流程，減低失誤及詐騙風險。截至2018年底，已有12間銀行加入成為該聯盟成員。「貿易聯動」與歐洲貿易融資平台「we.trade」於10月簽署《諒解備忘錄》，進行對接雙方平台的概念驗證。金管局亦同步探討「貿易聯動」與其他地區對接的機會，包括與新加坡金融管理局合作推出「全球貿易連接網絡」。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左）於「貿易聯動」啟動儀式上。

為培育更多金融科技專才，金管局於1月與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作推出「金融科技人才培育計劃」升級版(FCAS 2.0)。FCAS 2.0設有4個項目，適合處於不同職涯發展階段的年輕人才。計劃下有200多名學生受惠。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左二）與數碼港主席林家禮博士（左一）、香港應科院主席王明鑫先生（右二）及香港科技園公司行政總裁黃克強先生（右一）出席FCAS 2.0啟動儀式。

# 跨境合作

繼於2017年與深圳市人民政府金融發展服務辦公室（深圳金融辦）簽署《諒解備忘錄》後，金管局繼續加強與深圳的金融科技合作。當中包括金管局贊助「深圳金融科技暑期實習計劃」，讓50名學生到深圳多間著名公司進行為期6星期的實習，體驗當地的金融科技生態；另與深圳金融辦第二次合辦「深港金融科技創新獎」。

金管局副總裁李達志先生（右二）與首批深圳金融科技暑期實習生交談。

金管局亦於2018年與瑞士金融市場監督管理局、波蘭金融監管局、阿布扎比國際金融中心金融服務監管局及巴西中央銀行簽署金融科技合作協議，促進金融科技合作。

在8月，金管局與11間金融監管當局和相關機構公布「全球金融創新網絡」計劃。該網絡旨在為創新型公司提供更有效方式與監管機構進行互動，並促進監管機構之間就創新相關議題的合作。

# 虛擬銀行

引入虛擬銀行將會為香港金融科技應用增添新動力，並為數碼銀行客戶帶來嶄新體驗。虛擬銀行以個人或中小企等零售客戶為對象，因此亦有助促進普及金融。經公眾諮詢，金管局於5月發出《虛擬銀行的認可》指引修訂本，並於8月底接獲約30宗申請。

# 金融科技監管沙盒

年內沙盒的使用穩步上升。為協助建立金融合規科技的生態系統，沙盒於9月起開放予金融合規科技的項目。

截至2018年底，共有42項金融科技或科技產品獲准使用沙盒進行測試，其中28項已完成試行，有關產品亦已於其後推出市場。金管局另接獲220項使用「金融科技監管聊天室」的個案，希望在金融科技項目構思初期取得監管反饋意見。其中有約70%的個案來自科技公司。

# Hong Kong's status as an international financial center.

Consolidating Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre is one of the HKMA’s primary responsibilities. Seven initiatives aimed at promoting the development and application of financial technology by the banking and payments industries have made good progress this year, with the successful launch of the Faster Payment System “Faster Payments” being a prime example.

The optimization measures for the mutual market access programs between Mainland China and Hong Kong, along with the development of the Greater Bay Area, have further strengthened Hong Kong’s unique position as a key gateway to Mainland China. Hong Kong’s status as a global offshore RMB business hub has also been solidified, with vibrant RMB financial activity in the city.

At the same time, the HKMA is committed to exploring new opportunities and further enhancing the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform, including infrastructure financing, corporate treasury centers, and the green bond market. The HKMA is also strengthening its marketing efforts to promote Hong Kong’s advantages to stakeholders both overseas and on the Mainland. On the international front, the HKMA plays a leading role in various regional and international committees, clearly demonstrating Hong Kong’s expertise and commitment in related international work.

# Overview

To strengthen Hong Kong’s position as a leading FinTech hub in Asia, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to implementing the seven measures announced in September 2017 to promote the development and application of financial technology by the banking and payments industries. Key progress made this year on the seven initiatives to promote smart banking includes:

Successfully launched the fast payment system “Faster Payment System” (FPS), fully connecting different banks and stored value payment tools (collectively referred to as “e-wallets”).
Published the banking industry Open Application Programming Interface (Open API) framework and promoted the industry’s implementation of Open APIs.
Enhanced financial technology research and talent development.
Strengthened cross-border financial technology cooperation.
Revised the “Guideline on Authorization of Virtual Banks” and processed virtual bank license applications.
The upgraded version of the “Fintech Supervisory Sandbox” (FSS 2.0) is operating smoothly.
And expanded “BankEasy” to promote the adoption of RegTech by banks.

The Financial Technology Promotion Office (FFO) under the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with various banking departments within the HKMA, plays a crucial role in promoting and implementing the aforementioned measures.

With the implementation of optimized measures for the mutual market access schemes between Mainland China and Hong Kong, Hong Kong’s unique position as a primary gateway to the Mainland market has been further strengthened. The full implementation of the “Bond Connect” scheme with simultaneous delivery versus payment (DvP) settlement, and the State Council’s announcement of tax exemption arrangements for overseas investors investing in the Mainland’s bond market, have further enhanced the scheme’s efficiency and attractiveness. The HKMA has also been working closely with Mainland authorities to explore and implement a number of financial supporting measures to facilitate individuals and businesses living, working, and doing business in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (Greater Bay Area). Hong Kong’s offshore RMB business continues to thrive, with the pool of RMB deposits increasing by 6% year-on-year to RMB 657.7 billion; the average daily transaction volume of the RMB Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) system reached a high of RMB 1,010.1 billion.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is actively exploring new opportunities to further enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform. To promote the development of the Hong Kong bond market, the HKMA has implemented the “Bond Subsidy Pilot Programme” outlined in the Financial Budget, providing subsidies to institutions issuing bonds in Hong Kong for the first time. It is also working closely with the Government to amend legislation to broaden the scope of bond investment income eligible for tax exemption under the “Corporate Debt Issuance Programme.” Furthermore, the HKMA is strengthening its marketing efforts to promote Hong Kong’s advantages to stakeholders both overseas and in Mainland China, including organizing a number of large-scale and specialized outreach events to promote Hong Kong as a hub for green finance, infrastructure financing, and corporate treasury centres.

At the international level, the HKMA leads a number of regional and international committees. The HKMA currently chairs the Global Regulatory Cooperation Working Group under the Financial Stability Board, the Supervisory and Implementation Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (Basel Committee), and the Financial Market Work Group under the Executives’ Meeting of East Asia and Pacific Central Banks (EMEAP).

The safe and effective operation of Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure lays a solid foundation for its status as an international financial center. The four Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) systems handling interbank transactions, the Central Money Markets Unit (CMU) system, and the Hong Kong Securities Clearing and Settlement System (Hong Kong Securities Depository) all achieved 100% system availability in 2018, exceeding the target level of 99.95%. Through accounts maintained with two central securities depositories on the Mainland, the CMU system continues to facilitate the settlement of northbound trading under the Bond Connect scheme, as well as holding Mainland debt securities on behalf of relevant CMU system members.

To promote the overall safety and efficiency of the retail payment industry, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) designated two additional retail payment systems in August under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the “Payment Ordinance”), bringing their operation under the HKMA’s supervision. To date, the number of designated retail payment systems supervised by the HKMA has increased to six. The HKMA also regulates 16 licensed stored value facility operators, who are actively launching new products and services to provide customers with more choices and a better user experience. Simultaneously, the coverage of electronic cheques and electronic bill payment and presentment services has been further expanded to include cross-border payment transactions between Hong Kong and the entire Guangdong Province.

## 2018 Retrospective

# Hong Kong as an Asian Fintech Hub

# Measures to Promote Smart Banking

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced seven initiatives to promote smart banking in September 2017, with the aim of helping the banking sector reach a higher level and seize the vast opportunities presented by the convergence of banking and technology. The HKMA has made good progress within the year in implementing these measures and transforming the financial landscape of Hong Kong.

# Quick-witted.

"Faster Payments System" successfully launched in September, enabling bank and stored value payment tool users to conduct real-time fund transfers in Hong Kong dollars and Renminbi across banks anytime, anywhere, simply by entering the recipient’s mobile phone number or email address. A total of 21 banks (including most retail banks) and 10 stored value payment tool operators have joined the system, providing customers with instant payment services and/or account linking services.

“QuickPass” has already received over 2 million registrations within 3.5 months, representing 27% of Hong Kong’s population. Since its launch, the system has processed over 4.8 million transactions, involving a total value exceeding HK$104.9 billion and RMB 2.75 billion.

In the same month, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched the Hong Kong Retail Payment Shared QR Code Standard and its related mobile application, “Hong Kong QR” (HKQR). This is the world’s first mobile application to integrate multiple QR codes into a single, unified QR code, facilitating merchants – particularly small and medium-sized enterprises – to accept payment solutions from different payment service providers using a single QR code, eliminating the need to display multiple QR codes to customers.

# Open Application Interface

Open APIs refer to banks opening up their relevant data to third-party service providers, allowing for better and more convenient integration of banking services with other industries. Users can enjoy comprehensive services within a secure environment using a single system. To promote the development and provision of open APIs within the banking sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued the Open API Framework in July. The framework adopts a risk-based approach and implements various open API functions in four phases. As of January 31, 2019, 20 banks had opened approximately 500 open API interfaces in the first phase, covering data for over 1,000 products and services.

# Research and Talent Development

A consortium of banks in Hong Kong launched “TradeConnect,” a trade finance platform based on distributed ledger technology (DLT), in October, building on the proof-of-concept results led by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. The platform aims to reduce errors and fraud risks by digitizing trade documents and automating trade finance processes. As of the end of 2018, 12 banks had joined the consortium. In October, TradeConnect signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the European trade finance platform “we.trade” to conduct a proof-of-concept integration between the two platforms. The HKMA is also simultaneously exploring opportunities to connect TradeConnect with other regions, including collaborating with the Monetary Authority of Singapore to launch the “Global Trade Connectivity Network.”

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Chief Executive Eddie Yue (left) at the launch ceremony of "Trade Connect."

To cultivate more fintech talent, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) upgraded its “Fintech Capability Assessment and Sponsorship” (FCAS) programme in January, collaborating with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) to launch FCAS 2.0. FCAS 2.0 comprises four projects catering to young talent at different stages of their careers. Over 200 students have benefited from the programme.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Chief Executive Eddie Yue (second from left) attended the FCAS 2.0 launch ceremony with Hong Kong Digital Port Chairman Charles Lim (first from left), Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute Chairman Wong Ming-sham (second from right), and Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation CEO Albert Wong (first from right).

# Cross-border collaboration

Following the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding with the Shenzhen Municipal Government Financial Services Office (Shenzhen Financial Office) in 2017, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has continued to strengthen its financial technology cooperation with Shenzhen. This includes the HKMA sponsoring the “Shenzhen Fintech Summer Internship Program,” enabling 50 students to undertake six-week internships at various prominent companies in Shenzhen and experience the local fintech ecosystem. Additionally, the HKMA co-organized the “Shenzhen-Hong Kong Fintech Innovation Awards” with the Shenzhen Financial Office for a second time.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Deputy Chief Executive Li Tak-ji (second from right) speaks with the first group of Shenzhen FinTech summer interns.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also signed FinTech cooperation agreements in 2018 with the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority, the Polish Financial Supervision Authority, the Financial Services Regulatory Authority of the Abu Dhabi Global Market, and the Central Bank of Brazil, to promote cooperation in financial technology.

In August, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, along with 11 other financial regulatory authorities and related institutions, announced the “Global Financial Innovation Network” initiative. The network aims to provide innovative firms with a more effective way to engage with regulators and to foster collaboration among regulators on innovation-related issues.

# Virtual Bank

The introduction of virtual banks will inject new impetus into Hong Kong’s financial technology applications and bring a novel experience to digital banking customers. As virtual banks target retail customers such as individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises, they will also help promote financial inclusion. Following a public consultation, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued the revised Guideline on Authorization of Virtual Banks in May and received approximately 30 applications by the end of August.

# Financial Technology Regulatory Sandbox

Sandbox usage has been steadily increasing throughout the year. To assist in building a financial compliance technology ecosystem, the sandbox was opened to FinTech projects starting in September.

As of the end of 2018, a total of 42 financial technology or technology products had been approved to use the regulatory sandbox for testing, of which 28 had completed the trial phase and subsequently launched into the market. The HKMA also received 220 cases seeking feedback from regulators in the early stages of conceiving fintech projects through the “Fintech Regulatory Chatroom.” Approximately 70% of these cases originated from technology companies.

# 儲備管理

2018年對投資者而言是困難的一年，投資環境備受多項風險因素困擾，包括美國利率持續正常化引發金融狀況收緊、主要經濟體之間的貿易摩擦升級，以及全球多處民粹主義抬頭及地緣政治風險加劇。環球股市普遍向下，美國國庫券收益率亦隨着美國聯邦儲備局4次加息而上升。在美息趨升下，美元轉強。部分新興市場面對國內嚴峻的政治及經濟壓力，其貨幣顯著下挫。儘管投資環境充滿挑戰，外匯基金在2018年仍錄得109億港元投資收入。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產配置中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一及未來基金與外匯基金附屬公司存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎部分的總和。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但主要以未來基金除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2018年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重約為50:50。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置，即投資基準反映的配置情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，對資產進行戰略性配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局於8月成立外匯基金投資辦公室，專責投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約72%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分的投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約28%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，以取得可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專業投資技術知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，突顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況。金管局已加強風險評估，以配合外匯基金越趨多元化的投資；另採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，以識別促成不同表現的成因，藉此評估如何充分利用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資。例如，金管局已採納證券及期貨事務監察委員會公布的《負責任的擁有權原則》。該套原則旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局已就環境、社會及管治因素制定內部指引，適用於外聘基金經理的甄選、委任及監察程序。獲委任負責主動式管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理，須在管理有關投資時遵守《負責任的擁有權原則》。整體而言，金管局已將環境、社會及管治因素納入投資及相關監察活動的內部程序。金管局會密切注視環境、社會及管治因素的相關標準的發展，並評估如何能夠將這些標準進一步融入投資程序。此外，為促進負責任投資的國際合作，金管局已成為非牟利組織FCLTGlobal的成員，該組織旨在推動長遠目標為本的業務及投資決定。

# Inventory Management

2018 was a challenging year for investors, with the investment landscape beset by a number of risk factors, including tightening financial conditions triggered by continued US interest rate normalization, escalating trade friction between major economies, and the rise of populism and heightened geopolitical risks in various parts of the world. Global stock markets generally declined, and US Treasury yields rose as the US Federal Reserve increased interest rates four times. The strengthening of the US dollar followed the rise in US interest rates. Several emerging markets, facing significant domestic political and economic pressures, experienced substantial currency depreciations. Despite the challenging investment environment, the Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$10.9 billion in 2018.

# Exchange Stabilization Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, directly or indirectly. It may also be used to maintain the stability and integrity of the monetary and financial system in Hong Kong, thereby preserving Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is accountable to the Financial Secretary for the operation and investment management of the Exchange Fund, in accordance with the powers delegated to it and the provisions for further delegation by the Financial Secretary.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has established the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:

(a) Preserve capital;
(b) ensure that the monetary base is at all times fully backed by highly liquid US dollar assets;
(c) ensure sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(d) seek to maximize investment returns, consistent with the foregoing (a) to (c), to preserve the fund’s long-term purchasing power.

These objectives comprehensively address the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and are reflected in the Fund’s portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

The Exchange Fund is broadly divided into two main portfolios: the Support Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Support Portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets, providing full backing for the monetary base in accordance with the provisions of the monetary authority system. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in the debt and equity markets of member economies of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, with the aim of preserving asset value and long-term purchasing power.

To better manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is diversifying a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets into a wider range of asset classes in a prudent and gradual manner, including emerging markets and Mainland bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging markets and Mainland bonds and equities are held by the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the Long-Term Growth Portfolio. The market value of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio is capped at one-third of the Exchange Fund’s accumulated surplus and the total of the portion of deposits of the Future Fund and the Exchange Fund’s subsidiaries that is linked to the Long-Term Growth Portfolio.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the Exchange Fund for strategic purposes. Due to the unique nature of this portfolio, its performance is not included in the assessment of the Exchange Fund’s investment performance.

# Regarding deposits in the Exchange Fund.

The Exchange Fund accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations from time to time, with interest rates generally linked to the performance of the investment portfolio, except for the Future Fund. The interest rate on Future Fund deposits is linked to the performance of both the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual rate depending on the weighting of the portfolios. At the end of 2018, the weighting of the Future Fund between the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio was approximately 50:50.

# Investment Process

The Exchange Fund’s investment process is based on strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation refers to the asset mix reflected in the investment benchmark, indicating the long-term asset allocation the Exchange Fund can make to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses strategic allocation as a guideline to make tactical allocations, aiming to generate returns exceeding the benchmark. Consequently, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (which is the strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual and benchmark allocations is known as “tactical deviation.” The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limits. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation and define the permissible range for tactical deviation. Portfolio managers can then select holdings within the permissible range of tactical deviation to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Exchange Fund Investment Office in August, dedicated to investment and related risk management functions. Staff of the office are directly responsible for managing approximately 72% of the Exchange Fund’s investments, including the entire supporting portfolio and a portion of the investment portfolio. This portion of the portfolio invests in global fixed income markets and implements the Exchange Fund’s macro risk management strategies through the use of derivatives.

# External Investment Manager

In addition to managing assets through internal staff, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority also employs external investment managers responsible for managing approximately 28% of the Exchange Fund’s assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of employing external investment managers is to leverage the best professional investment expertise available in the market for Exchange Fund investments, to achieve sustainable returns, and to allow the Exchange Fund to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as to gain market insights and professional investment knowledge.

Expenses related to hiring external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses are primarily subject to market factors and vary annually.

# Risk Management and Oversight

The investment environment is becoming increasingly complex, highlighting the importance of risk management. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has established stringent control measures and investment guidelines for both internally and externally managed investment portfolios, and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. The Authority has enhanced risk assessments to align with the increasing diversification of the Exchange Fund’s investments, and also employs risk management tools to assess market risk under both normal and severely adverse market conditions. The Authority also conducts detailed investment performance attribution analysis to identify the drivers of different performance outcomes, thereby evaluating how to best leverage the investment management expertise of both internal and external managers.

# Responsible Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority supports responsible investment. For example, the HKMA has adopted the Principles of Responsible Ownership published by the Securities and Futures Commission. These principles aim to help investors determine the best way to fulfill their ownership responsibilities in Hong Kong-listed companies. Regarding the management of the Exchange Fund, the HKMA has established internal guidelines on environmental, social and governance (ESG) factors, applicable to the selection, appointment and monitoring of external fund managers. External fund managers appointed to actively manage the Hong Kong equity portfolio are required to comply with the Principles of Responsible Ownership when managing these investments. Overall, the HKMA has integrated ESG factors into its internal procedures for investment and related monitoring activities. The HKMA will closely monitor the development of relevant ESG standards and assess how these standards can be further incorporated into its investment processes. Furthermore, to promote international cooperation in responsible investment, the HKMA has become a member of the non-profit organization FCLTGlobal, which aims to promote business and investment decisions with a long-term orientation.

## The 2018 Financial Market

In 2018, a number of risk factors that had previously been underestimated by the market all came to the surface, including the pace of U.S. interest rate normalization, the impact of U.S. government foreign trade policies and protectionism on global trade, and geopolitical risks. This resulted in significant volatility and adjustments in global financial markets.

The escalating US-China trade dispute has caused significant concern among investors, leading to fluctuating declines in emerging markets and the Hong Kong stock market since the end of January, with the Hang Seng Index falling as much as 27% from its high that month. Major stock markets in Europe and the US have also experienced substantial declines since the fourth quarter, recording double-digit percentage drops. Overall, global stock markets generally fell in 2018, with the MSCI World Index, covering developed market equities, down 10.4%, and the MSCI Emerging Markets Index down 16.6%.

In the bond market, due to the normalization of US monetary policy, US Treasury yields generally rose throughout 2018. However, the bond market still experienced fluctuations during the year. In the currency market, the US dollar strengthened this year following interest rate hikes in the United States. The US Dollar Index rose 4.4%, while major currencies such as the Euro and the Renminbi depreciated approximately 5% against the dollar. Furthermore, the currencies of some emerging markets suffered further setbacks due to domestic political and economic instability. For example, the Argentine Peso and the Turkish Lira fell by approximately 50% and 30% against the dollar, respectively. # 金管局員工

金管局是政府架構的一部分，但按非公務員條款聘請員工，吸引具適當經驗及專門知識的人才。作為公營機構，金管局不斷精簡工作流程，提高效率及成本效益。金管局致力維持精簡靈活的組織架構，並盡可能透過調配現有人手推行新措施及應付不斷增加的工作量。

金管局是提供平等就業機會的僱主，並確保員工能夠在沒有歧視的環境下工作。金管局的平等機會政策適用於聘用、薪酬與福利、表現評核、晉升、調職╱培訓機會及一般行為操守等方面。

金管局聘用、培訓及維持一支專業優秀的工作團隊，以履行政策目標及靈活應對工作要求的轉變。金管局要求其員工維持高水平的操守及道德標準，不論何時都恪守極高的個人行為及操守規範，並以金管局的最佳利益為依歸。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以保持其薪酬競爭力。

金管局按個別員工的工作表現，分配獲批准用作調整年度固定薪酬及浮動薪酬的款項；而適用於負責投資的員工的浮動薪酬制度，則旨在加強其投資表現與薪酬的連繫。助理總裁及以上職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，是由財政司司長經參考管治委員會的意見後批准，有關員工在會議討論到其薪酬的議案時會避席。主管及以下職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，則由金管局總裁根據財政司司長授權，並按照獲批准用作支付薪酬的整筆款項來決定。

# Organizational Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains effective communication with the community and the market through the media, its website, public education activities and other various channels, enhancing public understanding of the HKMA’s policies and operations. Throughout the year, the HKMA continued to strengthen corporate governance, including supporting staff in enhancing their professional capabilities, exercising stringent financial control and reinforcing information technology security, in order to address the challenges brought about by the implementation of new measures and an increasing workload.

# Stay Connected with the Public

# Media Relations and Social Media

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains close communication with the media to enhance its transparency and promote public understanding of its policies and work. In 2018, the HKMA held a total of 96 public media events, including 21 press conferences, 11 stand-up interviews, and 64 other public events. In addition, 39 media interviews were arranged throughout the year, and 462 bilingual press releases were issued, alongside the handling of a large volume of media inquiries on a daily basis.

To enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s core functions, the HKMA has hosted media briefings and workshops for local and overseas media, covering a variety of topics including the Linked Exchange Rate System, FinTech development, green finance, and infrastructure financing. In addition to enriching the content of its existing YouTube channel and LinkedIn page, the HKMA also launched its official Facebook page in July to further leverage social media for enhanced public communication.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Chief Executive Eddie Yue (left) and the Environment Bureau’s mascot “Big Waste” are collaborating through social media to promote the use of new banknotes for Lunar New Year red packets.

# Public Inquiry / Public Queries

The public enquiry service is an effective channel for enhancing public understanding of the HKMA’s key functions and operations. It handled 9,950 enquiries in 2018, approximately half of which related to banking policies and regulations, banking consumer matters, and banknotes and coins – specifically, coin collection schemes, banking products and services, banking-related guidelines and announcements, the Faster Payment System “Faster Payments”, virtual banks, and the 2018 series of Hong Kong banknotes.

# Publications

In addition to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) Annual Report, the HKMA published two issues of the “Monetary and Financial Stability Report (Half-Yearly)” and four issues of the “Quarterly Report” in 2018. It also regularly updated the data in the “Monthly Statistical Bulletin on Hong Kong’s Financial System,” providing the latest and specialized information and analysis on Hong Kong’s currency, banking sector, and economic affairs. Furthermore, the HKMA published a total of 13 “HKMA Insights” articles, elaborating on various topics related to the HKMA’s work.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Website

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 60,000 pages of information in English, Traditional Chinese, and Simplified Chinese, facilitating public access to the HKMA’s latest information. The website also contains the “Register of Authorized Institutions and Local Representatives” and the “Register of Authorized Institutions’ Securities Business Staff” maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the “Register of Licensed Stored Value Facility Operators” maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance. The website features dedicated webpages and prominent quick links to remind the public of the HKMA’s new initiatives, such as “Faster Payment System,” and important and timely matters, such as guarding against telephone fraud and the locations of cash collection vehicles under the coin collection scheme.

To promote the implementation of open application programming interfaces (APIs) in the banking sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is leading by example, having made open APIs available on its website starting in July to facilitate public access to important HKMA information. The first batch of 50 sets of open API-formatted data was successfully launched in July, covering areas frequently consulted by the public, such as statistical data on the banking system and Exchange Fund, as well as press releases and cash-in-transit schedules. The remaining 80 sets of data will be rolled out in phases before mid-2019. To further enhance public access to the latest news and information about the HKMA on its website, the HKMA is comprehensively revising the website’s design and content to make it more user-friendly. The completely redesigned website is expected to launch within 2019.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is leading by example in promoting the development and application of open APIs.

# Public Education Program

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre Tower 2. It aims to introduce the work of the HKMA to the public and enhance public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The centre comprises an exhibition hall and a library, and is open to the public for visits and use six days a week. The exhibition hall showcases the work of the HKMA, as well as the development of the monetary and banking systems in Hong Kong. Reading materials and exhibits are also available for research on Hong Kong’s currency, banking sector, and financial affairs.

The Currency Exhibition Zone at the Information Centre showcases the design, anti-counterfeiting features, production process, and other interesting facts about Hong Kong banknotes and coins. The zone underwent renovation in the first quarter of 2018, with the addition of numerous interactive elements, such as games that combine learning with fun, allowing visitors to learn about Hong Kong currency while enjoying themselves. In addition, the Currency Exhibition Zone now features an artful Bauhinia tree constructed from 2,018 transparent cubes made from shredded, unfit-for-circulation banknotes. This complements another artwork within the zone – a mosaic created using Hong Kong coins, creating a visually appealing contrast. The newly renovated Currency Exhibition Zone reopened on August 16th.

The Information Centre provides guided tours for visitors. Throughout the year, the Centre welcomed over 59,000 visitors and conducted more than 580 guided tours for schools and other groups (Figure 3). Since its opening in December 2003, the Information Centre has received a cumulative total of over 705,000 visitors. The library, adjacent to the exhibition hall, houses a collection of over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications for research on topics such as Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking. The library also maintains the “Register of Approved Institutions and Local Representative Offices” and the “Register of Securities and Futures Professionals” as stipulated in Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Staff

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is part of the government structure, but employs staff under non-civil service terms to attract talent with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. As a public organization, the HKMA continuously streamlines workflows and enhances efficiency and cost-effectiveness. The HKMA is committed to maintaining a lean and flexible organizational structure and, where possible, implements new initiatives and handles increasing workloads by reallocating existing staff.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is an equal opportunity employer and is committed to ensuring that employees are able to work in a non-discriminatory environment. The HKMA’s equal opportunities policy applies to all aspects of employment, including recruitment, compensation and benefits, performance appraisal, promotion, transfer/training opportunities, and general conduct.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority recruits, trains, and maintains a professional and highly capable workforce to fulfill its policy objectives and adapt flexibly to evolving job requirements. The HKMA requires its staff to uphold high standards of integrity and ethics, consistently adhering to the highest personal conduct and ethical norms, and acting in the best interests of the HKMA at all times.

# 2018 Organizational Structure Changes

The Exchange Fund Investment Office was established on August 1st, taking over the investment and related risk management functions previously handled by the Reserve Management Department and the Risk Management and Compliance Department. The establishment of the Exchange Fund Investment Office highlights the HKMA’s investment functions, enhances its institutional image, and enables it to respond more flexibly to market changes, in line with the continued expansion and diversification of Exchange Fund investment activities.

# Compensation and Benefits Policy and Salary Review Mechanism

The Financial Secretary, through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, receives input from its subordinate governance committees and, with reference to market compensation levels and practices, determines the salary and terms of service for Hong Kong Monetary Authority staff. The compensation package includes cash compensation and mandatory provident fund contributions, along with a range of basic benefits. Cash compensation comprises a fixed monthly salary (i.e., basic salary) and a variable pay component awarded annually based on employee performance.

The Financial Secretary reviews the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) staff remuneration annually, consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee to obtain advice from its governance committee. This review considers the governance committee’s assessment of the HKMA’s performance over the past year, the results of remuneration surveys for the financial industry conducted by independent human resources consulting firms, and other relevant factors. The remuneration of individual employees with outstanding performance may also be subject to special adjustments to maintain its competitiveness.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority allocates funds approved for adjusting annual fixed and variable compensation based on individual employee performance. The variable compensation scheme applicable to employees responsible for investment is designed to strengthen the link between their investment performance and remuneration. Adjustments to the fixed compensation and disbursement of variable compensation for Assistant General Manager and above are approved by the Financial Secretary after considering the views of the Governance Committee, and relevant employees recuse themselves from discussions on their own compensation proposals at meetings. Adjustments to the fixed compensation and disbursement of variable compensation for staff at the Manager level and below are determined by the Chief Executive of the HKMA, under the authorization of the Financial Secretary, and in accordance with the total funds approved for salary payments.

就財務報表審計而言，我有責任閱讀其他資料，從而考慮其他資料是否與財務報表或我在審計過程中得悉的情況有重大矛盾，或者似乎存有重大錯誤陳述。基於我已執行的工作，如果我認為其他資料存有重大錯誤陳述，我需要報告該事實。在這方面，我沒有任何報告。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities at Fair Value

Please refer to the notes to the financial statements 2.5, 2.6 and 40.1.

As of December 31, 2018, the Group’s financial assets measured at fair value totaled HK$36,935.89 billion, and financial liabilities totaled HK$11,338.29 billion.

93% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities are valued at fair value using quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 inputs), or are valued using valuation techniques with inputs based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The fair value of the remaining 7% of these financial assets is determined using valuation techniques, with parameters not based on observable market data (Level 3 parameters). These financial assets totaled HK$275.631 billion and primarily include unlisted investment funds.

Given the significant amounts involved and the reliance on estimates, the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value is a key audit matter.

Audit procedures regarding the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value include:

- Understand the valuation procedures for different categories of financial assets and financial liabilities, including related monitoring measures;
- Evaluate and test monitoring measures, including related application monitoring measures for computer systems;
- Obtain confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and financial liabilities;
- If market quotations are used, verify prices from independent sources;
- If the parameters of the valuation methods used are based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation methods are appropriate and whether the related assumptions are reasonable, and verify the parameters from independent sources; and
- If the parameters of the valuation methods used are not based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation methods are appropriate, and whether the related assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# Valuation of investment property measured at fair value.

Please refer to notes 2.12, 20, and 21 to the financial statements.

The Group’s investment properties are carried at fair value, totaling HK$25.321 billion as of December 31, 2018. The Group also has interests in 3 associate companies and 20 joint ventures, whose primary business is the holding of overseas investment properties, with a combined value of HK$44.336 billion. The fair value of these investment properties, whether held directly by the Group or by associate or joint venture companies, is primarily determined based on valuations from independent professional valuers. These valuations involve significant judgment and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Audit procedures regarding the valuation of investment properties measured at fair value include:

- Obtain and review valuation reports for investment properties directly held by the Group or held by associates or joint ventures, and verify that the fair value is determined based on the valuation as stated in the relevant valuation reports;
- Assess the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and
- Evaluate whether the valuation methods are appropriate and whether the relevant assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# The Auditor’s Responsibility for the Audit of Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free of material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards will detect all material misstatements.
